awd_titl_txt: Theory and Applications of Localized Kernel Bases to Meshfree Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
The need for analyzing and modeling data taken from scattered, irregularly placed sites arises frequently in diverse fields: atmospheric science, artificial intelligence, computer-aided design graphics, data mining, medical imaging, learning networks, and many other areas.  For example, weather prediction or climate modeling is based on geophysical data collected at scattered sites, by sensors on satellites, ground stations, or stations at sea.  Carrying out such tasks presents difficulties for traditional methods, which are based on collecting data at uniformly placed sites or which require constructing "meshes" (think wire fence) that must be carefully tailored to deal with the data sites involved.  Newer methods, the so-called kernel methods, are meshfree and can handle scattered data.  The investigators further develop the theory of kernel methods, on the basis of which algorithms can be developed that are easier to use, faster, less expensive to implement, and capable of handling data from a hundred thousand or more sites.

Scattered data problems present a challenge for any method, including the traditional kernel-type algorithms based on translates of one (conditionally) positive definite function.  Scattered data occur naturally in meshfree methods, machine learning, neural nets, and other situations.  Dealing with such data, ideally, requires local, stable bases, preconditioners, and other similar tools.  In recent work on the sphere and rotations in space where no boundary is present, the investigators have developed novel bases related to certain classes of kernels.  For problems where boundaries are inherent, their bases need further development.  One key part of this project involves a novel idea of extrapolating data slightly beyond the boundary of a compact domain to enhance the approximation power of the method.  Another key area of investigation involves local approximation orders for data that is far more general than the typical quasi-uniform assumptions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The need for analyzing and modeling data taken from scattered, irregularly placed sites arises frequently in diverse fields: computer-aided design graphics, data mining, medical imaging, learning networks, and geoscience, in addition to many other areas. For example, weather prediction or climate modeling is based on geophysical data collected at scattered sites, by sensors on satellites, ground stations, or stations at sea. Carrying out such tasks presents difficulties for traditional methods, which are based on collecting data at uniformly placed sites or that require constructing "meshes'' (think "wire fence") that must be carefully tailored to deal with the data sites involved. Newer methods, the so-called kernel methods, are mesh free and can handle ``scattered data.'' These methods use a basis constructed from radial basis functions (RBFs). Previous research done by the PI and collaborators furthered the development of these kernel methods, making them easier to use, faster, less expensive to implement, and capable of handling data from a hundred thousand or more sites. The research done in this project focused on using these mesh-free methods to attack three problems.

The first is extrapolation. The mesh free approximations discussed from sites near the boundary of that region. The reason is that there isn't any data available from across the boundary. The problem is then to extrapolate data derived from inside the region to points outside of it in a computationally efficient way. While extrapolation problems go back to the 1930's, and many such problems have had successful theoretical resolutions, practical, computationally efficient implementations were lacking. The PI and collaborators developed mesh-free kernel methods that provide substantially improved approximations near the boundary.

The second is approximating scientific data on "graphs." Here, a graph is an abstract version of a connect-the-dots game. The dots are vertices and the lines are edges. They can be used in tasks ranging from classifying the quality of wines to signal processing. The PI and collaborators developed kernel-type tools for approximation on graphs. In comparison with a standard method using a nearest neighbor rule (NNR), numerical tests showed that the new method performed better than the NNR method.

The third involves providing theoretical foundations -- i,e., approximation rates and stability under small changes in data -- for methods used extensively in many scientific applications: the Kansa method and finite difference methods, all of which are RBF based. The Kansa method has been in use for thirty years and finite difference ones for over twenty years. None of these have a solid theoretical  foundation. Currently their use is only based on ad-hoc empirical evidence.  Recently, the PI and colleagues have looked at these RBF mesh-free methods in the special case of the Helmholtz equation on the surface of a sphere (earth, say). The equation itself is relevant for atmospheric studies. Both approximation rates and stability were established for this case. The general case will be pursued in future work.
